title-group.article-title: Influence of dynamic seals on silt abrasion of the impeller ring in a centrifugal pump

abstract.p: The water flow and movement of silt in a prototype double suction centrifugal pump was simulated using an Euler–Lagrange multiphase flow model. Back-blade and J-groove configurations were adopted to protect the impeller ring from silt abrasion. Four back-blades and four J-grooves were considered. The results show that the relative velocity of water around the impeller ring is too low to move silt out of the spacing between the impeller and the casing, which results in a high silt concentration around the impeller ring. The high silt concentration around the impeller ring is the major contributor to silt abrasion of the ring. Back-blade and J-groove configurations are effective in reducing the silt concentration around the ring but extra friction loss is also introduced and the pump efficiency is decreased. Optimization of the length, position and number of back-blades, and the shape and number of J-grooves, decreases losses in pump efficiency and effectively protects the impeller ring. Case 4 for the back-blade and Case 8 for the J-groove were the most effective configurations in this study.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The double-suction centrifugal pump is widely used in the Yellow River irrigation district because of its large flow rate and high head. Because of the high silt concentration in the Yellow River, silt abrasion of the flow passage components in the pump is inevitable. The impeller ring is usually the component that is most seriously affected by silt abrasion. Its lifetime is only one-third that of impeller. Many scholars have researched silt abrasion in hydraulic machinery. Liu et al.1 studied the trajectories of solid particles in a centrifugal pump by high-speed photography. Yoshiro et al.2 studied silt abrasion of various coating materials. Chen et al.3 studied silt abrasion on the surface of a hydrofoil and measured the flow field by particle image velocimetry. Most researchers have focused on the damage to the blade, while neglecting the impeller ring. Liu et al.4 studied the sealing performance and energy characteristics of a slurry pump with back-blades by computational fluid dynamics (CFD). Kurokawa et al.5–8 proposed a J-groove to improve the performance of the pump and this proved effective. The back-blade and J-groove configurations are chosen as countermeasures to silt abrasion of the impeller ring because they can increase the radial velocity of water, which helps to reduce the silt concentration around the impeller ring.

With the development of CFD, three-dimensional (3D) multiphase flow in pumps has been simulated extensively to predict pump performance and optimize the impeller geometry.9,10 CFD has thus become a powerful and effective tool in pump design for industrial applications.11–13 In this paper, the water flow and movement of silt in a prototype double-suction centrifugal pump was simulated using an Euler–Lagrange multiphase flow model. Dynamic seals, including a back-blade and J-groove, were adopted to suppress silt abrasion of the impeller ring in the centrifugal pump. Four back-blades and five J-grooves were analyzed.

sec.title: Mathematical model
sec.p:
The 3D Reynolds-averaged Navier–Stokes equations for incompressible flow are as follows13 (1)∂ρ∂t+∂∂xi (ρui )=0
(2)∂(ρui)∂t+∂(ρuiuj)∂xj=-∂p∂xi+∂∂xj (μ∂ui∂xj )+∂τij∂xj where τij=-ρui'uj'¯ is the Reynolds stress.

The k-ɛ turbulence model was chosen to enclose the equations. Considering the rotating flow inside the pump impeller, the Renormalization Group (RNG) k-ɛ model, which is effective for strongly rotating flow, was adopted in this simulation.14,15

The Euler–Lagrange multiphase flow model was used to simulate silt motion. The equation for silt motion is (3)du→pdt=FD (u→-u→p )+g→ (ρp-ρ )ρp+F→ where, F is an additional acceleration term, FD(u-up) is the drag force, u is the water velocity, up is the velocity of silt, ρ is the water density, and ρP is the density of silt.

The Euler–Lagrange multiphase flow model, which is implemented in the commercial CFD software Fluent 13.0, can describe the interaction between silt and water and the collision of silt particles. All simulations were conducted using Fluent 13.0 software. The SIMPLEC algorithm was used for the pressure–velocity coupling.16–18 The second-order upwind difference scheme was used for the momentum, turbulent kinetic energy, and dissipation rate equations. The mass flow rate was defined at the inlet and the static pressure at the outlet. The roughness heights of the hub and casing were also considered.19 The sliding mesh model was used to simulate the rotor-stator interaction in the pump. After the balance of silt concentration in the inlet and outlet is achieved, the silt concentration in the flow passage is obtained. The silt concentration around the impeller ring is the major contributor to silt abrasion of the impeller ring. This was chosen as the major performance indicator for optimizing the back-blade and J-groove.

sec.title: Physical model
sec.p:
The computational domain is the flow passage from the inlet to the outlet, including the impeller and volute, as shown in Figure 1. The diameter of the impeller was 0.765 m, the rotation speed was 960 r/min, and the number of blades was eight. A 3D view of the impeller is shown in Figure 2. An unstructured mesh was used to discretize the computational domain because of its complex geometry. The total number of mesh cells was about 3,000,000. Figure 1.
3D perspective view of the double suction pump.
Figure 2.
3D perspective view of the impeller.

sec.title: Prototype pump
sec.p:
The operating conditions of the prototype pump and silt properties are shown in Table 1. Table 1.
Operating conditions and silt properties.
Discharge Q = 0.95 m3/s
Total head H = 71.0 m
Rotational speed N = 960 r/min
Silt concentration C = 2.832 kg/m3
Silt diameter d = 0.031 mm
Specific speed ns = 98.7
For the given boundary conditions, the computational head of the prototype pump is H = 71.82 m, with an error of only 1.15%. The mathematical model and boundary conditions were therefore acceptable.

Figure 3 shows the silt concentration on the impeller plate. The silt concentration around the impeller ring is obviously higher than that in other positions, which is the primary cause for rapid silt abrasion of the impeller ring. Figure 4 shows the relative velocity on the impeller plate. The relative velocity around the impeller ring is small and the radial component is almost zero. Movement of the silt particles out of the gap is difficult, which results in a high silt concentration around the impeller ring. Figure 3.
Silt concentration on the impeller plate (units: kg/m3).
Figure 4.
Relative velocity on the impeller plate.

sec.title: Back-blade
sec.p:
A back-blade is usually used in a pump for dynamic sealing.4 Backward-oriented back-blades, with a semicircular cross-section, were adopted in this work to accelerate the water flow and remove silt from the gap. A diagram of the back-blades is shown in Figure 5. The curvature angle of the back-blade was the same as that of the impeller blade. The cross-section of the back-blade was semicircular, with a diameter of 10 mm. In Figure 5, Lb is the arc length of the back-blade, L is the arc length of the impeller blade on the impeller plate and L0 is the arc length of the impeller blade from the head of the back-blade to the impeller ring. Four different Cases, corresponding to different dimensions and positions of the back-blades, are listed in Table 2. Figure 5.
Diagram of the back-blade.
Table 2.
Dimensions and positions of the back-blade for different cases.
Case Number of the back-blade L0 Lb
1 4 0.1 L 0.5 L
2 4 0.1 L 0.25 L
3 4 0.35 L 0.125 L
4 3 0.35 L 0.25 L

The silt concentration and the relative velocity on the impeller plate for Case 1 are shown in Figures 6 and 7, respectively. It can be seen from Figure 6 that the silt concentration is significantly reduced compared with that of Figure 3. The silt concentration around the impeller ring is approximately zero and the impeller ring can thus be protected from silt abrasion. Figure 7 shows that the radial component of the relative velocity is increased by the presence of back-blades, which makes the removal of silt particles in the gap easier. The pump efficiency was reduced by 5.01%. This can be readily understood because that the frictional loss is increased by the back-blades when they increase the relative velocity. It can be concluded that the presence of back-blades will inevitably lead to additional frictional loss and decrease unit efficiency. Figure 6.
Silt concentration on the impeller plate (Case 1).
Figure 7.
Relative velocity on the impeller plate (Case 1).

In Case 2, the back-blades were shortened by half compared with Case 1 to reduce the efficiency loss. Figure 8 shows the silt concentration on the impeller plate for Case 2. The silt concentration changed only slightly with shortened back-blades. The pump efficiency dropped by 4.04% in Case 2. This analysis shows that further optimization of the back-blades is possible. Figure 8.
Silt concentration on the impeller plate (Case 2).

In Case 3, the length of back-blades was shortened to 0.125 L and the back-blades were moved outwards. The silt concentration on the impeller plate for Case 3 is shown in Figure 9. It can be found from Figure 9 that the silt concentration around the impeller is higher than that of Case 2 but lower than that at the inlet. The pump efficiency of Case 3 dropped by 2.85%. It can be found from Cases 1–3 that it is impossible to simultaneously reduce the efficiency loss and the silt concentration. Figure 9.
Silt concentration on the impeller plate (Case 3).

In Case 4, the length of the back-blades was 0.25 L but the number of blades was reduced to three. Figure 10 shows the silt concentration on the impeller plate for Case 4. The silt concentration around the impeller is almost zero, so the impeller can be protected effectively. The pump efficiency of Case 4 dropped by 3.83%, which is a larger change than that of Case 3. Figure 10.
Silt concentration on the impeller plate (Case 4).

The above analysis shows that the efficiency loss can be reduced by shortening the length or decreasing the number of back-blades, but the silt concentration will be increased simultaneously. This research aims at extend the lifetime of impeller ring by reducing silt abrasion, so the most important indicator is the silt concentration around the impeller ring. In this simulation, Case 4 was considered to be acceptable.

sec.title: J-grooves
sec.p:
The J-groove was also chosen as a dynamic seal in this simulation, following the recommendation in Saha et al.6 Figure 11 shows a schematic view of the J-groove. Four different Cases (Cases 5–8), corresponding to different numbers, dip angle a, depth h, and width b of J-grooves are listed in Table 3. Figure 11.
Schematic view of the J-groove.
Table 3.
Specifications of J-grooves.
J-groove Case 5 Case 6 Case 7 Case 8
Number 70 35 35 35
Dip angle (°) 45 45 30 30
Depth (mm) 5 5 5 5
Width (mm) 20 40 40 40
Face-1 Vertical Vertical Vertical Inclined

In Case 5, seventy J-grooves were adopted. The silt concentration on the impeller plate for Case 5 is shown in Figure 12. It can be seen from Figure 12 that the silt concentration on the impeller plate is significantly reduced comparing with that of Figure 3. The silt concentration around the impeller ring is approximate zero and the impeller ring can be protected from silt abrasion. As analyzed in section ‘back-blade’, the friction loss is increased by the J-grooves when increase the relative velocity. The pump efficiency dropped by 4.21% in Case 5. Figure 12.
Distribution of silt on the impeller plate (Case 5).

In Case 6, the number of J-grooves is reduced to 35 and the width b is increased to 40 mm. Figure 13 shows the silt concentration on the impeller plate for Case 6. It can be seen from Figure 13 that the maximum silt concentration on the impeller plate changed little but that around the impeller ring increased. The pump efficiency dropped by 3.50%. The silt concentration and the pump efficiency are thus unacceptable. It can be concluded that the shape of the J-groove should be optimized to achieve acceptable silt concentration and pump efficiency. Figure 13.
Distribution of silt on the impeller plate (Case 6).

In Case 7, the dip angle is decreased to 30°. The silt concentration on the impeller plate for Case 5 is shown in Figure 14. Figure 14 shows that the silt concentration around the impeller ring is approximately zero and the impeller ring is effectively protected. The pump efficiency of Case 7 dropped by 3.55%, which is better than in Cases 5 and 6 with regard to silt concentration and unit efficiency. Figure 14.
Distribution of silt on the impeller plate (Case 7).

In Cases 5–7, face-1 was designed to be vertical. In Case 8, face-1 was designed on an incline, to increase its area. Figure 15 shows the silt concentration on the impeller plate. It can be seen from Figure 15 that the silt concentration around the impeller ring changes little in Case 8 but the distribution on the impeller plate changes somewhat. The pump efficiency in Case 8 dropped by 3.11% and is considered to be the final acceptable case in this simulation. Figure 15.
Distribution of silt on the impeller plate (Case 8).

The above analysis shows that the J-groove is also effective in protecting the impeller ring from silt abrasion. The pump efficiency loss can be reduced by reducing the number of J-grooves, but the silt concentration will be increased simultaneously. The shape of the J-groove should be optimized to obtain a suitable silt concentration and unit efficiency.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p:
The water flow and movement of silt in a prototype double-suction centrifugal pump was simulated using an Euler–Lagrange multiphase flow model. Back-blade and J-groove configurations were designed to protect the impeller ring from silt abrasion. Four different back-blades and five different J-grooves were simulated and analyzed. The results show the following.
The radial component of relative velocity around the impeller ring is too low to move the silt particles out of the space between the impeller and the casing, which results in a high silt concentration around the impeller ring and rapid silt abrasion of the ring.
Back-blades and J-grooves are effective in reducing the silt concentration around the impeller ring but extra frictional loss is also introduced and the pump efficiency is decreased, simultaneously.
With optimization of the back-blade and J-groove configurations, Case 4 for the back-blade and Case 8 for the J-groove are considered acceptable both for protecting the impeller ring from silt abrasion and maintaining pump efficiency.
